desc: The power or skill to do something.
example: She has the ability to solve complex problems.

desc: An unexpected event that causes harm or damage.
example: He broke his leg in a car accident.

desc: The period between childhood and adulthood.
example: Adolescence is a time of emotional and physical changes.

desc: A young person going through adolescence.
example: Adolescents often seek independence from their parents.

desc: Feeling fear or worry.
example: She was afraid of the dark.

desc: Quick to notice and respond to danger or problems.
example: The guard stayed alert throughout the night.

desc: A strong feeling of displeasure or hostility.
example: He couldn’t control his anger during the argument.

desc: The joint between the foot and the leg.
example: She twisted her ankle while running.

desc: Drugs used to treat bacterial infections.
example: The doctor prescribed antibiotics for the infection.

desc: A feeling of worry or nervousness.
example: She felt anxiety before the exam.

desc: Feeling worried or uneasy.
example: He was anxious about the job interview.

desc: Feeling guilty or embarrassed about something wrong.
example: She was ashamed of lying to her friend.

desc: The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere.
example: Changes in atmospheric pressure can affect the weather.

desc: A strip of cloth used to cover a wound or injury.
example: The nurse wrapped a bandage around his arm.

desc: To hit your head against something.
example: He banged his head on the cupboard door.

desc: To lose too much water from your body.
example: After running in the sun, he became dehydrated.

desc: The red liquid that flows in your body.
example: Blood carries oxygen to the organs.

desc: Tubes in the body that carry blood.
example: Blood vessels can become blocked by fat.

desc: The hard part inside the body that forms the skeleton.
example: She broke a bone in her arm.

desc: The lowest part of something.
example: The keys were at the bottom of her bag.

desc: Medicines used to treat bacterial infections.
example: The doctor prescribed antibiotics for the infection.

desc: A feeling of worry or nervousness.
example: He felt anxiety before the exam.

desc: Feeling worried or nervous.
example: She was anxious about the results.

desc: Feeling guilty or embarrassed about something wrong.
example: He felt ashamed after lying to his friend.

desc: The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere.
example: Atmospheric pressure decreases with altitude.

desc: A strip of material used to cover a wound.
example: He wrapped a bandage around his arm.

desc: To hit your head against something.
example: I banged my head on the cupboard door.

desc: To lose too much water from your body.
example: It's easy to become dehydrated in the desert.

desc: The red fluid that circulates in the body.
example: Blood carries oxygen to the organs.

desc: Tubes that carry blood through the body.
example: Blood vessels expand during exercise.

desc: The hard parts that make up the skeleton.
example: He broke a bone in his arm.

desc: The lowest part of something.
example: The book was at the bottom of the bag.

desc: The organ that controls thoughts and body functions.
example: The brain needs oxygen to function.

desc: To fracture a bone in your body.
example: She fell and broke a bone in her wrist.

desc: To injure your body and cause dark skin marks.
example: He bruised himself badly during the match.

desc: To damage your skin with something hot.
example: Be careful not to burn yourself with the kettle.

desc: The back part of the lower leg.
example: My calves hurt after running.

desc: A serious disease caused by cells growing uncontrollably.
example: He is receiving treatment for lung cancer.

desc: The side of the face below the eye.
example: She kissed him on the cheek.

desc: The front upper part of the body between the neck and stomach.
example: He had pain in his chest.

desc: The lower part of the face below the mouth.
example: He stroked his chin while thinking.

desc: To manage or deal with something successfully.
example: She coped well with the stressful situation.

desc: Russian astronauts who travel into space.
example: The cosmonauts trained for months before the mission.

desc: A thick substance used for healing or moisturizing.
example: Apply this cream to the burn twice a day.

desc: Slightly angry or annoyed.
example: She was cross because he forgot her birthday.

desc: To injure yourself deeply with a sharp object.
example: He cut himself badly while slicing vegetables.

desc: The first light of the day; sunrise.
example: They left the house at dawn.

desc: Feeling extremely sad and hopeless.
example: He felt depressed after losing his job.

desc: A mental condition marked by deep sadness.
example: She was diagnosed with clinical depression.

desc: A dry, sandy area with little rain or vegetation.
example: The Sahara is the largest hot desert in the world.

desc: To break down food in the stomach.
example: It takes time to digest a heavy meal.

desc: Feeling strong dislike or disapproval.
example: She was disgusted by the mess in the kitchen.

desc: A time far ahead from now.
example: Space tourism may be common in the distant future.

desc: Someone who gives blood, organs, or money.
example: He became a blood donor at 18.

desc: A protective cover placed over a wound.
example: The nurse changed the dressing on his leg.

desc: The time just before night when the light fades.
example: They returned home at dusk.

desc: The joint between your upper and lower arm.
example: He leaned on his elbow while reading.

desc: To release or send out something, like light or gas.
example: The machine emits a high-pitched sound.

desc: Wanting what someone else has.
example: He was envious of her success.

desc: A feeling of wanting what someone else has.
example: Her talent was the envy of the entire class.

desc: The necessary tools or gear for a specific purpose.
example: The gym has all the latest equipment.

desc: The line of hair above the eye.
example: She raised her eyebrow in surprise.

desc: The fold of skin that covers the eye.
example: His eyelids felt heavy from lack of sleep.

desc: An unpleasant emotion caused by danger or threat.
example: He has a fear of heights.

desc: A high body temperature caused by illness.
example: She stayed in bed with a high fever.

desc: The flat part of the face above the eyes.
example: He wiped sweat from his forehead.

desc: Easily broken or damaged.
example: Be careful — that vase is fragile.

desc: Injury caused by freezing of the skin or tissue.
example: He got frostbite from climbing without gloves.

desc: To lose a lot of blood from the nose.
example: She had a bad nosebleed during class.

desc: A bruise around the eye, usually from injury.
example: He had a black eye after the fight.

desc: The organ that pumps blood in the body.
example: Exercise helps keep your heart healthy.

desc: Medical conditions affecting the heart.
example: Smoking increases the risk of heart disease.

desc: The back part of the foot below the ankle.
example: The shoes hurt my heel.

desc: An elevated location far above sea level.
example: Breathing is harder at high altitudes.

desc: The part of the body where the leg joins the torso.
example: She fell and injured her hip.

desc: A feeling of expectation for something good.
example: We never lost hope during the rescue.

desc: The arms and legs of a person.
example: Robots can now imitate human limbs.

desc: Material that makes up the human body.
example: Scientists grew human tissue in the lab.

desc: The amount of moisture in the air.
example: The humidity made it hard to breathe.

desc: The long tube in the body that processes food.
example: The small intestine absorbs nutrients.

desc: The bone structure that forms the mouth and holds the teeth.
example: He broke his jaw in the accident.

desc: An organ that filters waste from the blood.
example: The patient had a kidney transplant.

desc: The joint between the thigh and lower leg.
example: She injured her knee while running.

desc: The length of time someone lives.
example: The average human lifespan is increasing.

desc: The soft edges of the mouth.
example: He bit his lip nervously.

desc: A small reptile with scales and a long tail.
example: A lizard darted across the rock.

desc: An organ used for breathing.
example: Smoking damages your lungs.

desc: The science of treating illness.
example: She studies medicine at university.

desc: A hormone that regulates sleep.
example: Melatonin helps you fall asleep.

desc: Tissue in the body that helps you move.
example: You need strong muscles to lift weights.

desc: The hard covering at the end of a finger or toe.
example: She painted her nails red.

desc: An extremely small microchip used in advanced technology.
example: The doctor implanted a nano-chip to monitor health.

desc: One of the two openings of the nose.
example: He pinched his nostrils to stop the bleeding.

desc: A gas essential for breathing.
example: Plants release oxygen during photosynthesis.

desc: Medicine used to reduce or stop pain.
example: He took painkillers for his headache.

desc: A polite way of saying someone has died.
example: Her grandfather passed away peacefully.

desc: To lose consciousness.
example: He passed out from the heat.

desc: A statement about what will happen in the future.
example: The weather prediction was accurate.

desc: To stop something from happening.
example: Exercise helps prevent disease.

desc: A feeling of satisfaction about achievements.
example: She felt pride in her work.

desc: To suggest an idea or plan for consideration.
example: He proposed a new solution to the problem.

desc: Feeling deep satisfaction because of achievements.
example: She was proud of her son's success.

desc: To completely change something, especially by improving it.
example: Technology has revolutionised communication.

desc: One of the curved bones surrounding the chest.
example: He cracked a rib while playing football.

desc: An amphibian that looks like a lizard and lives in damp places.
example: A salamander crawled out of the pond.

desc: The skin covering the top of the head.
example: He had a cut on his scalp.

desc: A painful feeling from guilt or embarrassment.
example: He felt deep shame after lying.

desc: The front part of the leg below the knee.
example: She bruised her shin on the table.

desc: The joint between the upper arm and torso.
example: He carried the bag over his shoulder.

desc: The outer covering of a person's or animal's body.
example: Her skin was soft and smooth.

desc: The bone structure that forms the head.
example: The skull protects the brain.

desc: A small spacecraft used for transport to and from space.
example: The astronauts landed safely in the space capsule.

desc: The column of bones down the back that supports the body.
example: Injuries to the spine can be serious.

desc: To injure the wrist by twisting it suddenly.
example: I sprained my wrist while playing basketball.

desc: An organ in the body where food is digested.
example: He had a pain in his stomach.

desc: To try hard to do something difficult.
example: She struggled to finish her homework on time.

desc: The total amount resulting from addition.
example: He paid a large sum of money.

desc: Something unexpected or unusual.
example: The party was a wonderful surprise.

desc: Feeling or showing surprise.
example: He was surprised by the sudden rain.

desc: To continue to live or exist after a difficult situation.
example: They survived the storm without injury.

desc: A portable shelter made of fabric supported by poles and ropes.
example: We slept in a tent during the camping trip.

desc: The part of the leg between the hip and the knee.
example: He injured his thigh while running.

desc: Having length, width, and depth.
example: The model was three-dimensional and very realistic.

desc: The front part of the neck, or the space inside the neck used for swallowing and breathing.
example: She had a sore throat.

desc: The short, thick first finger on the hand.
example: He gave a thumbs-up sign.

desc: One of the five small parts at the end of each foot.
example: I stubbed my toe on the chair.

desc: Medical care for an illness or injury.
example: She is receiving treatment for cancer.

desc: To injure your ankle by turning it suddenly.
example: He twisted his ankle while playing football.

desc: Having the usual qualities of a particular group or thing.
example: It's a typical day in autumn—cool and rainy.

desc: Extremely important or necessary for life.
example: Drinking water is vital for health.

desc: The part of the body between the ribs and hips.
example: She tied the belt around her waist.

desc: Over a large area or among many people.
example: This book is widely read around the world.

desc: A small, long, soft-bodied animal with no legs.
example: He found a worm in the garden soil.

desc: The joint connecting the hand with the forearm.
example: She wore a watch on her wrist.

desc: A photographic image of the inside of the body.
example: The doctor took an X-ray of her chest.
